Course Title: Disaster Recovery, Climate Change, and Government Response


Course Location: 1599 Clifton Rd room 5c


This course will be held on the following dates: Mar 18, Mar 25, Apr 1, Apr 8, Apr 15, Apr 22, Apr 29


As climate change accelerates, human communities are faced with unprecedented weather and climate disasters. These threaten community well-being, people's aspirations for the future, and the very livability of different parts of the planet. How do governments respond to these growing calamities? Through a case study of the US Federal Disaster Recovery & Mitigation process, this course will provide students insight into the practice, management and implementation of federal disaster response programs.
Disaster response includes both addressing immediate hardships and long-term recovery programs that cover infrastructure, housing, and economic development needs. In this course, students will gain concrete skills by considering these challenges through a case scenario: they will create an Action Plan to demonstrate community needs following a disaster and future disaster risks and prepare for the implementation of a disaster recovery program of their choosing.
Taught by consultant practitioners working in Disaster Recovery, the course provides unique insight into federal grant management processes, monitoring and auditing, and the role of specialized consultants. Given the increasing pace of climate disasters, such skills will be sure to serve students with many development interests.
course_description: Applied Development is a module-based course through which experts from leading global development agencies (CARE, Habitat, World Bank, etc.) present students with a practical approach to various components of global development. Topics of discussion may include microfinance, resettlement, housing, market inclusion, education, or health topics. Experts allow students increased access to development agencies, while offering a practical approach to lectures and in-class exercises. Many of these modules and activities will be tied to case-studies and hands-on learning activities.
